characters: EXT. PITCH AND PUTT GOLF COURSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The soundtrack opens with Frank Sinatra's "Fly Me to the Moon". A HELICOPTER SHOT OF THE L.A. basin. The pool of golden light disintegrates into the thousands points which constitute it as we rapidly draw closer to t city. We are just above the tops of the highest buildings as we approach Hollywood Boulevard.  Below is neon and the icy thrust of search lights rotating on the corner of Hollywo and Vine. We continue west, then quickly north. There is the momentary appearance of the moonlit HOLLYWOO sign as we pass the blinking red beacon of the Capital Records building and drop into Franklin avenue and over t 101. Architectural remnants of Hollywood's past whip up.  We a heading east at treetop level.  A warm glow in the distan quickly grows into a modest commercial strip which includ cafes, bookstores, and a theater. We drop to eye level as we spy through the plate glass showcase window of the "Bourgeois Pig" coffeehouse, which holds the translucent reflection of the full moon. A cigarette wedged between knuckles smoulders.  MIKE take the last drag with great effort, then crushes it out.  He sits in the window sprawled across a red velvet couch tha once perfectly complemented a faux spanish foyer.

dialogues.speaker: WINDOW
dialogues.text: ROB sits down next to Mike, pouring himself some tea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what if I don't want to give up on her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you said I shouldn't call if I wanted to give up on her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I don't call either way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the difference?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only difference between giving up and not giving up is if you take her back when she wants to come back.  See, you can't do anything to make her want to come back.  You can only do things to make her not want to come back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the only difference is if I forget about her or pretend to forget about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well that sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It sucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So it's almost a retroactive decision. So I could, like, let's say, forget about her and when she comes back make like I just pretended to forget about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right...or more likely the opposite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right...  Wait, what do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean first you'll pretend not to care, not call - whatever, and then, eventually, you really won't care.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unless she comes back first.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, see, that's the thing.  Somehow they don't come back until you really don't care anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the rub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the rub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man.  Sorry we always talk about the same thing all the time...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, don't sweat it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...It's just that you've been there. Your advice really helps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob, I just want you to know, you're the only one I can talk to about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.  Thanks, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close up on answering machine.  Mike pushes the button.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Hello, you have five messages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike's eyes light up.  He paces in anticipation as the ta rewinds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (male voice) Hey, baby.  It's Trent.  I hope you're feeling better about your old girlfriend. I hope my advice helped...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike fast-forwards to next message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Skipping message. (male voice) Whatsup, Mike.  If you want to talk some more about Michelle... (synthesized voice) Skipping message. (female voice) Mike, it's Chris.  Feeling better yet about...? (synthesized voice) Skipping message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tension grows with every inch of spooling tape.  Did she leave a message?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (female voice) Hi, Mike.  Did she call yet?  If she didn't then she doesn't deserve... (synthesized voice) Skipping message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last one.  It's a long shot, but he's got the faith.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (elderly female voice) Michael, this is Grandma.  I want to know if you got the part on that television program.  I told the whole family and they're very excited to know if... (synthesized voice) Skipping message.  End of final message.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lighting a cigarette, defeated) Shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) You have to put things in perspective.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unfazed by the sentient appliance) I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) You've been through worse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right.  I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Ever since I've known you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Moving here from New York was much more of an adjustment than this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It didn't feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) That's because it was a challenge.  You has control over you're situation.  It was hard, but you rose to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.  I'll think about that.  Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) You really should.  Life, after all, is really just a series of challenges...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (growing irate) Enough.  I've got to use the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Are you calling Her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Stop, come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LED goes black as the machine beeps off.  Mike picks the phone and hits autodial. Machine beeps off.  Phone rings again, then is answered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over phone) Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: S'up Trent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lemme get off the other line, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear the clicks of call-waiting-hold limbo.  The silen is interrupted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice over phone) You should call your Grandmother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shuddup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (returning to line) That was Sue.  We got two parties tonight.  One's for a modeling agency.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to me, baby, there are going to be beautiful babies there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent, I don't feel like going out tonight.  I got shit to do tomorrow...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen to you.  I got an audition for a pilot at nine and I'm going.  You gotta get out with some beautiful babies.  You can't sit home thinking about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I don't know- listen to you.  We're gonna have fun tonight.  We gotta get you out of that stuffy apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're gonna spend half the night driving around the Hills looking for this party and then leaving cause it sucks, then we're gonna look for this other party you heard about.  But, Trent, all the parties and bars, they all suck.  I spend half the night trying to talk to some girl who's eyes are darting around to see if there's someone else she should be talking to.  And it's like I'm supposed to be all happy cause she's wearing a backpack.  Half of them are nasty skanks who wouldn't be shit if they weren't surrounded by a bunch of drunken horny assholes.  I'm not gonna be one of those assholes.  It's fucking depressing.  Some skank who isn't half the woman my girlfriend is is gonna front me?  It makes me want to puke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (beat) You got it bad, baby.  You need Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?  Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: VEGAS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What Vegas?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tonight, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're crazy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pick you up in a half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going to Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up- yes you are.  Now listen to Tee. We'll stop at a cash machine on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A long thoughtful pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't lose more than a hundred.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just bring your card.  Half an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you wearing?  I mean, we should wear suits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh...  Now Mikey wants to be a high roller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, seriously, if you're dressed nice and you act like you gamble a lot, they give you free shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay Bugsy.  Twenty minutes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wear a suit, I'm telling you it works.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be downstairs.  You're beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is dressed to the nines in classic vintage threads. He's trying to look at ease as he straightens his cuff li He approaches Trent who suavely leans against his worn do ride.  He's a tall, slim, good-looking cat.  His sharkski suit hangs well on his lanky frame as it tapers to his ankles.  Sinatra's "Come Fly With Me" on the tape deck ad an elegance to the scene.  They exchange an impish grin a depart without saying a word.  Maybe this isn't such a ba idea.

dialogues.speaker: SPEEDOMETER
dialogues.text: The NEEDLE IS PINNED.  The gauges are blurred by the vibration of the poorly tuned engine.  The SHOT WIDENS to reveal that the "Oil" and "Service" dummy lights are both illuminated, causing an eerie red glow onto TRENT's white knuckles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent's car is red-lined.  The SWINGERS are Vegas bound. not pass go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (counting bills) I took out three hundred, but I'm only gonna bet with one.  I figure if we buy a lot of chips, the pit boss will see and they'll comp us all sorts of shit, then we trade back the chips at the end of the night.  You gotta be cool though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cool, baby.  They're gonna give Daddy a room, some breakfast, maybe Bennett's singing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious.  This is how you do it.  I'm telling you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  Daddy's gonna get the Rainman suite.  Vegas, baby.  We're going to Vegas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas!  You think we'll get there by midnight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Baby, we're gonna be up by five hundy by midnight.  Vegas, baby!

dialogues.text: Vegas!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas!

dialogues.text: The needle is still buried.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (stirring) Whu?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at it, baby.  Vegas, baby!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent points out a mountain range.  It is now the only th separating them from their destination.  The surreal glow the desert sky is accentuated by the loud slashing of the cobalt and ruby lasers emanating from a source masked by the craggy peaks.  Mike slowly stirs from his slumber.  H transfixed by this affrontation of nature.  It is his fir glimpse of the city without God.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in reverie) Vegas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shrill cry of Basie's fat brass section heralds the arrival of the young swingers.  Their eyes drink every wa of golden light as Sinatra's crooning urges them on. Mike has either had enough sleep or so little that it no longer matters.  Either way, there's no turning back. They roll up to a casino valet.  TILT UP to a skull and crossbones which looms overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two guys walk and talk down a fluorescent hallway.  I well past midnight and the only patrons at this hour are tourists too drunk to sleep and compulsive gamblers who s out of their rooms without waking their wives. It is a weeknight and it is beginning to become painfully obvious that our boys are overdressed. The decor is nautical plaster.  Castings of bearded men w primitive prosthesis clutching daggers between their teet are everywhere. All of ye olde promenade shoppes are closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (the first budding of crankiness) Pirates of the fucking Caribbean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the hot new place, besides, you love pirates.  Tell me Mikey doesn't love pirates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fuckin' post-pubescent Disneyland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta love the pirates, baby.  The pirates are money.

dialogues.text: The corridor empties into the equally kitch CASINO.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This place is dead.  I thought this was the city that never sleeps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's New York, baby.  You should know that.  Look at the waitresses.  I'm gonna get me a peg-leg baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gonna screw up our plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: Mike is at a blackjack table with Trent at his side.  The game has paused to observe the newcomers as Mike draws a billfold out of his breast pocket.  They're pulling it of with only slightly noticeable effort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I guess I'll start with three hundred in, uh, blacks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (hastily laying down the bills) Oh... right.

dialogues.text: The dealer lays out the bills such that the amount is vis to the camera encased in the black glass globe overhead. Trent and Mike look up at it open-mouthed like turkeys in rain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Blacks?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.text: You want this in black chips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, that'll be fine.

dialogues.text: The dealer chirps out an unintelligible formality and the BOSS chirps the response.  Trent's focus whips away from camera as both he and Mike stare at the pit boss ten feet away. The dealer plunks down the measly THREE CHIPS which repre Mike's entire cash reserve.  Not quite the effect he had hoped for. The swingers stare at the chips.  The players stare at th swingers.  The dealer stares at the pit boss.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have anything smaller?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, but I'm afraid this table has a hundred-dollar-minimum bet.  Perhaps you'd be more comfortable at one of our lower stakes tables.

dialogues.text: The dealer indicates a FIVE-DOLLAR TABLE across the room where an Hispanic woman deals to a BLUEHAIR, a BIKER, and COUPLE in matching Siegfried and Roy T-shirts. The swingers look back to the dealer who is now flanked b the pit boss. The tense silence is broken by...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Drinks? (then to Trent) How about you, Cap'n?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent looks over to see that it's the same WAITRESS who flashed him a smile earlier.  At first he begins to smile then, remembering that he is locked in a high stakes batt of wills, subtly shakes her off.  She smirks and starts t leave until she is interrupted by Mike holding up a finge It's a balsy move, but everyone's watching.  The kid's go for broke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to the waitress, but never breaking eye contact with the dealer) I'll have a vodka martini, straight up, shaken not stirred, very dry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Smooth.  Trent is impressed, but masks his pride.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (under her breath cynically as she writes it down) One "James Bond".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (regaining composure) No.  Blacks will be fine.

dialogues.text: Mike throws a chip in the circle.  Trent is shocked.  Tha a hundred bucks.  Mike and Trent share a look.  The deale and the pit boss exchange glances.  Bets are all down and cards are meticulously dealt. The dealer has a two showing.  Mike has been dealt a five a six- eleven.

Here comes the bust... Flick - four.  Sixteen!  Here comes the bust... Flick - five.  Twenty one.  Groans all around, except for swingers who watch their chips slide away in silence. Mike breaks the spell with a plucky smile from the pit of stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Always, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: What's that?  One twenty?  You're up twenty bucks, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I need the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're an actor.  Find the Zen in the role.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's definitely a step back for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, there's not much of a call for Shakespeare in this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's just something about being "Goofy".  Any other Disney character would be fine.  There's just this stigma associated with the character.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you want?  You're tall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you realize how hard it's going to be to tell my parents?  I still haven't told them I didn't get the pilot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You tested over a month ago.  I'm sure they figured it out by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like "Hi, Mom.  I'm not going to be starring in that sit-com and, oh by the way, I'm Goofy.  Send more money."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They split up and both over-chip the green miserably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike and Rob putt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Haven't you noticed I didn't mention Michelle once today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't want to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It's like not talking to a pitcher in the midst of a no hitter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  Like, you didn't want to jinx it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't talk about her that much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mention her once today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, until now.  Tend the pin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike pulls out the flag for Rob's putt.  He misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only reason I mentioned her at all is to say that I'm not going to talk about her anymore.  I thought you'd appreciate that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do.  Good for you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've decided to get out there. (re: the ball) Go ahead.  Play it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob putts the "gimme".  He misses by an inch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not making any more excuses for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob taps it in.  He tends the pin or Mike, who misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good to hear, Mikey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike putts again, and misses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to hit the town tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I shouldn't, Mike, it's a weeknight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have?  A Pluto call back?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Kick me when I'm down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike plunks it in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Count 'em up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them count and recount as they revisualize eac shot in their head.  Throughout the process they count un their breath and point to different parts of the fairway green. The two of them revolve, point, and mumble for an absurdl long amount of time until finally...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many strokes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Eight or Nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll give you an eight. (writes score)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An eight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Looks like we're in a dead heat after one hole.  This is turning into quite a rivalry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob points to the far-off crowd of a dozen IRATE GOLFERS Waiting to tee off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You better replace the pin, Chi-Chi.  The natives look restless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First of all, SUE is a guy, and a tough guy at that.  He wearing an L.A. Kings home jersey.  His sweater bears the sacred number "99".  Sue is lounging in front of the TV i army surplus khaki cutoffs and untied Doc Martin boots. Sue brushes back a shock of straight, greasy, dirty blond hair as not to obscure his view of the screen.  His face glows with the reflection of the SEGA HOCKEY game on the Sue and TRENT are locked in a heavily contested battle of motor reflexes.  Nothing moves but their eyes, thumbs, an mouths...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch... You little bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chelios to Roenick...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE looks on.  He is more captivated with the simulated sporting event than the Clippers game on the TV across th room. Electric guitars blaze over the stereo. The room, like the guys, could use a spring cleaning.  Pi boxes, beer bottles, and full, full ashtrays.  You can ta the smoke.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You little bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Sue.  Gretsky's on his ass again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's a bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so bullshit.  This is so bullshit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should play another team.  The Kings are bitches in this game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man.  I took the Kings to the Cup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... against the computer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a finesse team...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're a bitch team... SCORE! Roenick!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck!!!  That is so bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give it up, Sue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHONE RINGS.  Sue picks it up and balances it on his shoulder as he plays.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? (re: game) Shit! (back to phone) Yeah.  The elevator doesn't work. (he lets the phone drop.  Then to Mike) It's Pink Dot.  Buzz him in - hit nine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike picks up the phone off the matted shag carpet.  He pushes "9", listens, then hangs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wish the game still had fights so I could bitch-slap Wayne.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This version doesn't have fighting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Doesn't that suck?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?  That was the best part of the old game.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  I guess kids were hitting each other or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could make their heads bleed, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah... If you hit them hard their heads bleed all over the ice and their legs convulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kinda money, actually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make someone bleed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man, we're in the play-offs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll make Gretsky bleed, the little bitch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The DELIVERY MAN knocks on the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pause it. (Trent pauses the game)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me the money.  I'll get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: While Sue gives Mike the money, Trent UNPAUSES the game a checks Gretsky into the boards, leaving him writhing in a pool of red pixels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sue dives onto Trent.  They wrestle a little too rambunctiously for indoors.  Trent pulls the hockey sweat over Sue's head and starts wailing on his back. Mike crosses.  The CAMERA follows him down a shallow hall to the door.  He unlocks it. A delivery man of eastern-hemispheric decent is out of br from four flights of stairs.  He hands Mike a twelve-pack Bud cans and three packs of Marlboro reds. He can HEAR, but NOT SEE, the chaos ensuing in the living room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and Sue are flushed.  They pause long enough to tor Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (feigning homosexuality) Is he cute?  Ask him if he wants to stay for a cocktail!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (following suit) ... Is he brown?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike forces an apologetic smile.  He is embarrassed.  The delivery man doesn't seem to understand any of this. Mike, out of guilt, hands him a four dollar tip.  This he seems to understand.  He smiles and leaves. Mike crosses back to the main room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are such assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing the gag) Aww... He got away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (untangling himself from Trent) Gimme my reds.  I've been jonesing for an hour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike throws him a pack of smokes, which he unravels with surgical precision. Cans of beer are tossed around and cracked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What time's this party tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It starts at eight...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... which means no one will get there 'til ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what?  Eleven?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Midnight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm gonna bring and old friend who just moved out here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?  Rob?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You met him once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (approvingly) Yeah.  He's a "rounder".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to be an actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a surprise...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... How novel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MIKE and ROB walk down the dirty deserted alleyway.  Mike wearing baggy slacks, Doc Martin shoes, and an oversized Eisenhower-cut jacket with a vertical stripe inset.  The collar is large and pointy, but definitely not seventies. His ensemble has more of an early sixties vibe. Rob hasn't been at it quite as long.  He's wearing worn-i Levies over worn-in boots and, the nineties standby, an untucked flannel. Mike walks with purpose.  He intermittently tries to pull open locked steel doors along the alley.  Rob looks confu

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, if the party starts at eight, why are we first going to a bar at ten?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To get a drink before we meet the guys for a bite at eleven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. (beat) Where is this place?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling handle) It's one of these.  For some reason, cool bars in L.A. have to be very hard to find and have no signs out front.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That doesn't sound too good for business.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pull) It's kinda like a speakeasy kind of thing.  It's kinda cool.  It's like you're in on some kind of secret.  You tell a chick you've been some place, it's like bragging that you know how to find it.  The only way you could know where a place is is if someone who knows brought you there.  You have to have someone come before.  There is a direct line connecting you back to the original, unequivocally cool, club patrons.  It's kinda like Judaism...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds more like Aids...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... That's probably a more appropriate analogy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At this point they come upon an unmarked BLACK METAL DOOR which Mike successfully pulls open to reveal...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A smoke-filled, windowless, black-walled room.  There are several round padded booths lining the walls.  The place packed, and the funk standard "Brick House" throbs over t P.A.. A HANDHELD SHOT as the two guys serpentine to the mirrore bar at the far end of the room.  Enshrined in its center a framed photograph of SINATRA smiling in approval as he presides over the evening's activities. Mike proudly points out the photo to Rob.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kinda money, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Classy.

dialogues.text: Mike catches the attention of a cute female BARTENDER.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll get a Dewars rocks... (looks to Rob)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...A Dewars on the rocks and a Bud, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't get over how cute the girls in this city are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know.  It's like the opposite of inbreeding.  The hottest one percent from around the world migrate to this gene pool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darwinism at its best.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been around here six months and I still can't get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like, every day I see a beautiful woman.  I'm not used to that.  I'm used to seeing a beautiful woman, I don't know, once a week.  I can't handle it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait till summer.  I swear, you can't leave the house.  It hurts.  It physically hurts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait till I actually get to touch one of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, there's the rub...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's the rub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bartender serves them their drinks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (o.s.) Whassup Mikey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike turns to see CHARLES.  A young black man with a tigh Dolomite fro.  He wears a black leather blazer over a bla turtleneck.  Just look up "cool" in the dictionary. A handshake turns into a hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles!  What's up, man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  You know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you, um, did you get that pilot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, man.  I know you didn't get it 'cause you wouldn't've asked me.  It wasn't that funny anyway...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... piece of shit.  Listen, Charles, this is my friend Rob from Back East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My pleasure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles and me went to network on this pilot together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just tested for one...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... yeah, a month ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm sorry.  How'd your folks take it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I haven't heard an official "no" yet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't told then, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I still haven't told my folks I didn't get "Deepspace 9".  You'd think they'd'a figured it out by now, but Mom keeps asking...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and boy does it hurt when they ask.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't even tell them about anything I'm close on anymore...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... not until you book it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... and even then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... you might get cut out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm considering taking a job as a "Goofy".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, man.  At least it's Disney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to come with us to a party at the Chateau Marmont?  They got a bungalow and lots of beautiful babies.

dialogues.text: (yelling over the roar of the wall to wall crowd) Why not?  This place is dead anyway.

dialogues.text: MIKE, TRENT, SUE, CHARLES, and ROB sit around the round scotch-plaid corner booth of the retro-hip coffee shop. of our boys, with the exception of Rob, are classily dres They wear a lot of black, brown, and gray with a splash o gold and maroon. The CAMERA REVOLVES around the table in a repeating "Reservoir Dogs" style over the shoulder 360 DEGREE PAN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... No, baby.  I got a better one.  You gotta admit the steadycam shot in "Goodfellas" was the money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... What's the big deal?  Everyone steals from everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Well, let's hit that party.

dialogues.text: The five swingers walk down the boulevard in a SLO-MO SHO which is extremely "derivative" of the "Reservoir Dogs" credit sequence. The scene is choreographed to Bennett's big band arrangem of "O SOLE MIO".

The music, the conversations, all movement, everything. Everyone in the room STARES at them standing in the doorw Beat. The music starts back up and everyone returns to their conversations. The swingers weave their way through the crowd to...

dialogues.text: Damned if I know...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Beats me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... I came with you.

dialogues.text: What's that guy's name?  Sue?

dialogues.text: Sue.  His dad was big Johnny Cash fan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, like that song...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: You're a better man than I am, Charlie Brown.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.text: No!  She's not looking at you.  She hasn't looked at you once.  Will you stop asking if...  Wait, she just looked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No problem, buddy.  You eat anything today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike shakes his head, "no".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yesterday?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike shakes his head again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You haven't been drinking, have you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Just O.J.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rob cuts into the pepperoni with his Swiss army knife.  M drinks his juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry about what happened at the Dresden. I had no idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sweat it.  Now I got an L.A. gun story.  You should hear the way I tell to the guys back home.  He had an Uzi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike half-smiles. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want to talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the point?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been two days.  You should call that girl Nikki...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike grabs his head in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uuuuugh!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm such an asshole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wasn't your type anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'm gonna move Back East.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's dumb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's dumb about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you're doing so well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How am I doing well?  I host an open mike and I played a fuckin' bus driver in a movie.  Big fuckin' deal.  I'm with an agency that specializes in fuckin magicians.  How good am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At least you didn't get turned down for Goofy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They turned you down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They went for someone with more theme park experience.  I woulda killed for that job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike lets it sink in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, it's all how you look at it.  If your life sucks, then mine is God awful. I mean, I moved out here partially because I saw how well you were doing. You got in the union, you got an agent. I thought if you could make it, maybe I could too...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't make it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's your problem, man.  You can't see what you've got, only what you've lost. Those guys are right.  You are "money".

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike smiles, then...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (starting to cry) Then why won't she call...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you left, man.  She's got her own world to deal with in New York.  She was a sweet girl but fuck her.  You gotta move on.  You gotta let go of the past. The future is so beautiful.  Every day is so sunny out here.  It's like Manifest Destiny man.  I mean, we made it.  What's past is prologue.  That which does not kill us makes us stronger.  All that shit.  You'll get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you get over it?  I mean how long 'til it stopped hurting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes is still hurts.  You know how it is, man.  I mean, each day you think about it less and less.  And then one day you wake up and you don't think of it at all, and you almost miss that feeling. It's kinda weird.  You miss the pain because it was part of your life for so long.  And the, boom, something reminds you of her, and you just smile that bittersweet smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see that Mike has been GNAWING AWAY at Rob's pepperoni semolina as he listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You miss the pain?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... for the same reason you miss her. You lived with it so long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. (finishing the loaf) You wanna grab a bite?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He helps Mike up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, the guys back home said she put on some weight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) You always know the right thing to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent opens the door.  He sees Mike standing there dresse for trouble.  His face lights up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mikey!  Guys, Mikey's here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (from the living room) Mikey!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike HEARS the sound of a hotly contested SEGA MATCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch!  You little bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The CAMERA follows Mike and Trent into the...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike's JAW DROPS when he sees that Sue has been playing hockey against the BALD GUY from the Dresden.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bitch!  You bitch!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is filled with the BALD GUY'S CREW.  They greet as they take hits off their forty ouncers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent.  Take over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do a high-speed "controller handoff." Sue crosses to Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry, man.  You were so right. I got rid of the gun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are they doing here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We ran into them that night at Roscoe's. Tee cleared it up, I apologized, bought them some chicken and waffles.  They fuckin love Tee.  That boy can talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All the baldies howl and slap hands at something funny Te said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But most important, man, I'm sorry about what I said.  I was drunk...  My adrenaline was going...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't sweat it, man.  I needed a kick in the ass.  We're better friends for it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, man. (they hug) I've been hating myself for the last two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Believe me, I know what that's like. (then to Trent) Yo, Double Down!  What time are we leaving?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Five minutes, baby.  Hey, it's been two days.  You should call Nikki and see if she wants to meet you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The THREE SWINGERS are waved pass the line by the doorman a Scorsese-style STEADICAM SHOT which continues up the st and through a curtained doorway into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the domed decco lounge and the full house part for them and greets them in perfect Scorsese choreography They pass the billiard table and the circular brass rail The six piece swing band decked out in zoot suits wail on stage as the crowded dance floor whirls. The swingers eventually settle into a dark curtained-off onstage booth. Sue thrusts a scotch into Mike's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Montage of smoking, drinking, and carousing. The parquet floor is packed with swinging hepsters dresse Hollywood's take on forties threads.  The dancing is full blown overcrowded slam swing.  The floor is full, and everyone is damn good.  This definitely aint amateur nigh

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike steps up to the bar to refill his drink.  He sees a BRUNETTE sitting at the bar. She's cute. Real cute. She glows. There's something fresh about her.  She's dressed nice, b different.  She definitely is not a regular. She throws Mike a half-smile, then looks away. He looks away. Should he? He shakes his head to himself.  No. Beat. He looks over at her again. Mike's P.O.V. of a WHITE BUNNY sitting on the bar stool. He smiles, shrugs, and CROSSES TO HER. When he gets to her she has reverted back to human form.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mike.  I'm Lorraine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like the quiche?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yes.  Like the quiche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like quiche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought real men don't like quiche.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My reputation seems to have preceded me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?  You're not a real man?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent points the conversation out to Sue from across the room. Trent and Sue's P.O.V. of Mike and Lorraine having an unforced, enjoyable conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... so I thought, what the hell, they make movies in L.A., not in Michigan, so I moved here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it wasn't the simple, but yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was it hard?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I left someone very special behind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell me about it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (lights up) I thought I was going to die.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been six months and I'm just starting to get over it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, God.  That's two more than me.  Tell me it gets better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiles) It does.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it still sucks, but you start to see that there are advantages to being single.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (coyly) Like what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What what?  What advantages?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You said there are advantages to being single.  I want to know what the advantages are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (playing along) Well... You can talk to a beautiful woman at a bar without worrying if anyone's watching you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and Sue are watching from across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...  it's definitely on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What else...?  Let's see...  You have complete freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.... To grow, to go out. Whatever you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like if I meet a handsome young man and I wanted to ask him to dance?  I can do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, if the guy wants to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't think the guy would find me attractive enough to dance with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I mean, no.  I mean, maybe he would find her, I mean you attractive.  Maybe he doesn't like to dance.  Maybe all he likes to do is just stand around and drink and smoke and look cool with his buddies who don't dance either...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it doesn't matter if he's a good dancer cause it's a slow song, if that's what he's afraid of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smirk) No... Maybe that's not the case.  Maybe she shouldn't be such a smug little shit because she'd be surprised at what a good dancer he really is, but it's been a long time and he doesn't know if he's ready to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She gets up.  She's beautiful.  She is beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Will you dance with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's in great shape,  and look how classy her vintage dr looks.  A vision from the forties.  She's too good for th place.  She belongs on the nose of a B-52.  What can he s but...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He awkwardly leads her to the unusually empty dance floor They START TO DANCE.  It's a slow song and they boringly back and forth.  Mike is self-conscious, but her touch. her touch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and Sue watching in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... it is so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple's dance is cut short as there were only a few left of the slow ballad.  Mike smiles politely in relief begins to lead Lorraine off the floor. She pulls him back.  He's not getting off that easy.  She wants a whole song.  He politely holds her, poised for another slow number.  They're alone on the floor. Much to Mike's dismay, the song begins with a DRIVING TOM SOLO.  This cues every hep cat in the Derby that the big one's coming.  They all flood the floor for the last danc the night. Mike pleadingly shakes his head at Lorraine.  It's too fa Her eyes narrow as her grip tightens.  No sympathy here. The band breaks into the full-tilt swing number and the d floor writhes around them. They stand motionless for what seems like an eternity. Gut check.  Fuck it.  Sink or swim. Mike grabs her like a man grabs a woman.  It's just a sim six-count swing step, but they're in perfect harmony. Mike and Lorraine look into each others eyes.  It's on, b As Mike's courage grows, the moves start to flow.  A spin first.  Then a double twirl.  It's not long before he's throwing her through combinations that stand out even amo the pros.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and Sue, mouths agape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is whipping her smoothly through violent-looking combinations without a trace of hesitation, and, boy, can follow. The set ends with a flourishing crescendo.  They're froze a final dip, panting through a glaze of clean sweat. Mike and Lorraine smile and look into each other's eyes. smile slowly disappears.  Will they kiss? They're close. Really close. Lips almost touching. Mike tries to muster-up the courage, but it's been so lon He can't do it.  He lets her up. The floor clears.  Exhausted dancers push past them.  For it.  The moment's gone. What the hell.  They had a great time.  What's the hurry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is walking Lorraine to her car.  They come upon a pa Escort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... This is it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen.  I had a great time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I would love to see you again sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not good enough.  I want to make plans to see you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me get a pen out of my car. (opens the door) Do you have something to write on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike hands her a business card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at it) You're a comedian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  And an actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll have to come see you sometime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If and when I get a real gig I'll call you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not going to well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I lived in New York they made it sound like they were giving out sit-coms to stand-ups at the airport.  I got off the plane in L.A. six months ago and all I got to show for it is a tan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Didn't you tell me to be patient with my career?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah, but entertainment law isn't something you just jump into...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither is acting.  Not if you're serious about it. (She writes her number on the card.) Can I have one of these?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you like the duck with the cigar? (hands her a card)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Nice touch.  It's the logo from "You Bet Your Life", right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good eye.  Not one club owner got it. They all ask me why I got Donald Duck on my card.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, at least it's not Goofy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I should be getting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's really getting late.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... home.  It's getting late.  Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I give you a ride to your car...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Nah.  I'm right across the street...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Which one...?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... The red piece of shit over there...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... well, it suits you...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... get the hell outta here already...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike leans in and slowly gives her the sweetest, softest, most innocent kiss. He backs up.  She's got that goofy look as she unlocks he club and starts the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She drives off. He watches her go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is driving Trent and Sue home in his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were off your ass back there!  Where the hell did you learn to do all that twirly whirly shit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took a ballroom class with Michelle. I never danced with anyone but her, til tonight.  That Lorraine chick is good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were good.  Did you see how she was vibing you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You probably coulda hit that tonight if you didn't have to drive us home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Definitely...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give me that!  She liked you, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know she liked me.  I mean, it's not like I wanted to do anything with her tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good for you, man.  He's being smart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's really special, guys.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bear's got his claws back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Be smart about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling you.  Wait three days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to wait three days...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Okay, two...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... just be smart about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Guys... Guys... I got it under control.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  He's got it under control...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Well, then, I guess we don't have to worry about him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our little baby's growing up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and sue pretend to cry and hug each other. Mike looks at them in the rear view mirror. He smirks and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys are such assholes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Trent and Sue scream at the top of their lungs as they cr down Sunset.  Alcohol is a terrible drug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is standing in the middle of the room looking at LORRAINE'S NUMBER on the back of the BUSINESS CARD. He looks at the clock. 2:45 A.M. He looks back at the NUMBER. Beat. He thinks better of it.  He wedges it into a crack in the answering machine and unbuttons his shirt for bed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) Good move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike smirks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike wakes up and rolls out of bed. He walks to the phone and pulls the CARD out of the crack He looks at the clock. 12:10 PM. He sticks it back in the crack. He makes an "x" on a day of his calendar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike brushes his teeth. He looks at the card clipped into the frame of the bathro mirror. He turns the faucet, allowing exactly ONE DROP of his precious Los Angeles water supply to drip onto his toothbrush. He resumes brushing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike sips espresso as he stares at the CARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike is playing solitaire with the CARD laying above all playing cards. The PHONE RINGS. Mike rushes to get it, then forces himself to wait anothe ring and a half exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michelle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's it going?  It's been a while...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Six months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine... I guess.  You?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. (pause) I think about things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What kind of things?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you met someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter.  I think about you every day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I miss you, Mike.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why didn't you call?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I couldn't.  Do you know how hard it's been not to call you?  I pick up the phone every night.  Whenever that commercial comes on...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... the Micheline commercial...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Yeah, with the baby in the tire.  One time I started to cry right in front of Pierre...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pierre... That's his name?  Pierre?  Is he French?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not... Listen I don't want to talk about him.  That's a whole other headache.  I called because I heard you might be moving back to Queens...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BEEP of Mike's CALL WAITING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hang on.  Let me get rid of this call.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks to the OTHER LINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Mike?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lorraine?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you on the other line?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can call back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no.  Hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He clicks back to the OTHER LINE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard you might be moving back...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, uh, I don't think that's gonna be happening any time soon...  Listen, can I call you right back?  I gotta take this call...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not home and going out of town tomorrow for a week.  Can't you talk for five more minutes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I really want to catch up with you, but I've gotta take this call.  They're holding.  I'll talk with you when you get back in town.  Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye.  I lov.....(click)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike SWITCHES LINES, cutting Michelle off mid-sentence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi.  Sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't have to get off the other line.  I would've called you back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's okay.  I wanted to talk to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike holds his palm over the receiver and looks at the answering machine. Beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to answering machine) Do you realize that I've been waiting for that call for six months and I cut her off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (synthesized voice) You're money, baby.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike smiles. Back to Lorraine. MEDIUM SHOT of Mike through his window as he looks down o Franklin avenue and talks on the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi, Lorraine.  Thanks for holding on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Mike.  You really didn't have to get off the line.  I just wanted to ask you one thing.  I know I shouldn't have called, I mean, my friends said I should wait two days... Oh God, I probably sound like such a schoolgirl... It's just that it's tonight only... I mean, it's Sinatra's birthday and they have this thing every year at "The Room".  Do you know where that is?  It's impossible to find if you've never been there.  I don't understand why none of the clubs in Hollywood have signs.  Anyway, I'm so bad at this, if you're not busy I thought you might...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mike smiles as the CAMERA PULLS BACK from the window and backwards down Franklin Avenue in a reverse of the first of the movie.  The soundtrack kicks in with Sinatra's "He To The Losers"....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to those who love not too wisely, no, not too wisely, but too well... To the girl who sighs with envy when she hears that wedding bell... To the guy who'd throw a party if he knew someone to call... Here's to the losers... Bless them all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...We rise and pass the glowing Hollywood sign. It's stil full moon...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to those who drink their dinners when that lady doesn't show... To the girls who wait for kisses underneath that mistletoe... To the lonely summer lovers when the leaves begin to fall... Here's to the losers... Bless them all...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: .... Past the blinking red beacon of the Capital Records building...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Tom, Dick and Harry... Come in out of the rain... Those torches you carry... Must be drowned in champagne...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... Up and over Hollywood Boulevard.  High above the city

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's the last toast of the evening... Here's to those who still believe... All the losers will be winners... All the givers shall receive... Here's to trouble-free tomorrows... May your sorrows all be small... Here's to the losers... Bless them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ... It's all just a pool of beautiful golden light.
